projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts uses TEI Simple to encode the Shakespeare texts edited by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptions and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Beggar ( Christopher Sly) and Hostess.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: I’ll feeze you, in faith.

sp.speaker: HOSTESS
sp.p: A pair of stocks, you rogue!

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
You’re a baggage! The Slys are no rogues. Look
in the chronicles. We came in with Richard Conqueror.
Therefore, paucas pallabris, let the world
slide. Sessa!

sp.speaker: HOSTESS
sp.p:
You will not pay for the glasses you have
burst?

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
No, not a denier. Go, by Saint Jeronimy! Go to
thy cold bed and warm thee.

sp.speaker: HOSTESS
sp.p:
I know my remedy. I must go fetch the
headborough.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I’ll answer him
by law. I’ll not budge an inch, boy. Let him come,
and kindly.

div.stage: Wind horns within. Enter a Lord from hunting, with his train.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Huntsman, I charge thee tender well my hounds.
Breathe Merriman ( the poor cur is embossed)
And couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach.
Saw’st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good
At the hedge corner, in the coldest fault?
I would not lose the dog for twenty pound!

sp.speaker: FIRST HUNTSMAN
sp.l: Why, Bellman is as good as he, my lord.
He cried upon it at the merest loss,
And twice today picked out the dullest scent.
Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Thou art a fool. If Echo were as fleet,
I would esteem him worth a dozen such.
But sup them well, and look unto them all.
Tomorrow I intend to hunt again.

sp.speaker: FIRST HUNTSMAN
sp.p: I will, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: What’s here? One dead, or drunk? See doth he breathe.

sp.speaker: SECOND HUNTSMAN
sp.l: He breathes, my lord. Were he not warmed with ale,
This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: O monstrous beast, how like a swine he lies!
Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!
Sirs, I will practice on this drunken man.
What think you, if he were conveyed to bed,
Wrapped in sweet clothes, rings put upon his fingers,
A most delicious banquet by his bed,
And brave attendants near him when he wakes,
Would not the beggar then forget himself?

sp.speaker: THIRD HUNTSMAN
sp.l: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.

sp.speaker: SECOND HUNTSMAN
sp.l: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Even as a flatt’ring dream or worthless fancy.
Then take him up, and manage well the jest.
Carry him gently to my fairest chamber,
And hang it round with all my wanton pictures;
Balm his foul head in warm distillèd waters,
And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet;
Procure me music ready when he wakes
To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound.
And if he chance to speak, be ready straight
And, with a low, submissive reverence,
Say “ What is it your Honor will command?”
Let one attend him with a silver basin
Full of rosewater and bestrewed with flowers,
Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper,
And say “ Will ’t please your Lordship cool your hands?”
Someone be ready with a costly suit,
And ask him what apparel he will wear.
Another tell him of his hounds and horse,
And that his lady mourns at his disease.
Persuade him that he hath been lunatic,
And when he says he is, say that he dreams,
For he is nothing but a mighty lord.
This do, and do it kindly, gentle sirs.
It will be pastime passing excellent
If it be husbanded with modesty.

sp.speaker: THIRD HUNTSMAN
sp.l: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part
As he shall think by our true diligence
He is no less than what we say he is.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Take him up gently, and to bed with him,
And each one to his office when he wakes.
Sirrah, go see what trumpet ’tis that sounds.
Belike some noble gentleman that means
( Traveling some journey) to repose him here.
How now? Who is it?

sp.speaker: SERVINGMAN
sp.l: An ’t please your Honor, players
That offer service to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Bid them come near.
Now, fellows, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: PLAYERS
sp.p: We thank your Honor.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

sp.speaker: FIRST PLAYER
sp.l: So please your Lordship to accept our duty.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: With all my heart. This fellow I remember
Since once he played a farmer’s eldest son.—
’Twas where you wooed the gentlewoman so well.
I have forgot your name, but sure that part
Was aptly fitted and naturally performed.

sp.speaker: SECOND PLAYER
sp.l: I think ’twas Soto that your Honor means.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: ’Tis very true. Thou didst it excellent.
Well, you are come to me in happy time,
The rather for I have some sport in hand
Wherein your cunning can assist me much.
There is a lord will hear you play tonight;
But I am doubtful of your modesties,
Lest, over-eying of his odd behavior
( For yet his Honor never heard a play),
You break into some merry passion,
And so offend him. For I tell you, sirs,
If you should smile, he grows impatient.

sp.speaker: FIRST PLAYER
sp.l: Fear not, my lord, we can contain ourselves
Were he the veriest antic in the world.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery
And give them friendly welcome every one.
Let them want nothing that my house affords.
Sirrah, go you to Bartholomew, my page,
And see him dressed in all suits like a lady.
That done, conduct him to the drunkard’s chamber,
And call him “ Madam,” do him obeisance.
Tell him from me, as he will win my love,
He bear himself with honorable action,
Such as he hath observed in noble ladies
Unto their lords, by them accomplishèd.
Such duty to the drunkard let him do
With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy,
And say “ What is ’t your Honor will command,
Wherein your lady and your humble wife
May show her duty and make known her love?”
And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,
And with declining head into his bosom,
Bid him shed tears, as being overjoyed
To see her noble lord restored to health,
Who, for this seven years, hath esteemed him
No better than a poor and loathsome beggar.
And if the boy have not a woman’s gift
To rain a shower of commanded tears,
An onion will do well for such a shift,
Which ( in a napkin being close conveyed)
Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.
See this dispatched with all the haste thou canst.
Anon I’ll give thee more instructions.
I know the boy will well usurp the grace,
Voice, gait, and action of a gentlewoman.
I long to hear him call the drunkard “ husband”!
And how my men will stay themselves from laughter
When they do homage to this simple peasant,
I’ll in to counsel them. Haply my presence
May well abate the over-merry spleen
Which otherwise would grow into extremes.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter aloft Christopher Sly, the drunkard, with Attendants, some with apparel, basin and ewer, and other appurtenances, and Lord dressed as an Attendant.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: For God’s sake, a pot of small ale.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Will ’t please your Lord drink a cup of sack?

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Will ’t please your Honor taste of these conserves?

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.l: What raiment will your Honor wear today?

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
I am Christophero Sly! Call not me “ Honor” nor
“ Lordship.” I ne’er drank sack in my life. An if you
give me any conserves, give me conserves of beef.
Ne’er ask me what raiment I’ll wear, for I have no
more doublets than backs, no more stockings than
legs, nor no more shoes than feet, nay sometime
more feet than shoes, or such shoes as my toes look
through the over-leather.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Heaven cease this idle humor in your Honor!
O, that a mighty man of such descent,
Of such possessions, and so high esteem
Should be infusèd with so foul a spirit!

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
What, would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher
Sly, old Sly’s son of Burton Heath, by birth a
peddler, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation
a bearherd, and now by present profession a
tinker? Ask Marian Hacket, the fat alewife of Wincot,
if she know me not! If she say I am not fourteen
pence on the score for sheer ale, score me up for the
lying’st knave in Christendom. What, I am not
bestraught! Here’s—

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.l: O, this it is that makes your lady mourn.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVINGMAN
sp.l: O, this is it that makes your servants droop.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house,
As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.
O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth,
Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment,
And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.
Look how thy servants do attend on thee,
Each in his office ready at thy beck.
Wilt thou have music? Hark, Apollo plays,
And twenty cagèd nightingales do sing.
Or wilt thou sleep? We’ll have thee to a couch
Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed
On purpose trimmed up for Semiramis.
Say thou wilt walk, we will bestrew the ground.
Or wilt thou ride? Thy horses shall be trapped,
Their harness studded all with gold and pearl.
Dost thou love hawking? Thou hast hawks will soar
Above the morning lark. Or wilt thou hunt?
Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them
And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Say thou wilt course. Thy greyhounds are as swift
As breathèd stags, ay, fleeter than the roe.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Dost thou love pictures? We will fetch thee straight
Adonis painted by a running brook,
And Cytherea all in sedges hid,
Which seem to move and wanton with her breath,
Even as the waving sedges play with wind.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: We’ll show thee Io as she was a maid
And how she was beguilèd and surprised,
As lively painted as the deed was done.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,
Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds,
And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep,
So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord;
Thou hast a lady far more beautiful
Than any woman in this waning age.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee
Like envious floods o’errun her lovely face,
She was the fairest creature in the world—
And yet she is inferior to none.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.l: Am I a lord, and have I such a lady?
Or do I dream? Or have I dreamed till now?
I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak,
I smell sweet savors, and I feel soft things.
Upon my life, I am a lord indeed
And not a tinker, nor Christopher Sly.
Well, bring our lady hither to our sight,
And once again a pot o’ the smallest ale.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Will ’t please your Mightiness to wash your hands?
O, how we joy to see your wit restored!
O, that once more you knew but what you are!
These fifteen years you have been in a dream,
Or, when you waked, so waked as if you slept.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.l: These fifteen years! By my fay, a goodly nap.
But did I never speak of all that time?

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Oh, yes, my lord, but very idle words.
For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,
Yet would you say you were beaten out of door,
And rail upon the hostess of the house,
And say you would present her at the leet
Because she brought stone jugs and no sealed quarts.
Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: Ay, the woman’s maid of the house.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Why, sir, you know no house, nor no such maid,
Nor no such men as you have reckoned up,
As Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greete,
And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell,
And twenty more such names and men as these,
Which never were, nor no man ever saw.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: Now, Lord be thanked for my good amends!

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: I thank thee. Thou shalt not lose by it.

div.stage: Enter Page as Lady, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: How fares my noble lord?

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
Marry, I fare well, for here is cheer enough.
Where is my wife?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: Here, noble lord. What is thy will with her?

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.l: Are you my wife, and will not call me “ husband”?
My men should call me “ lord.” I am your goodman.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: My husband and my lord, my lord and husband,
I am your wife in all obedience.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.l: I know it well.— What must I call her?

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: “ Madam.”

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: “ Alice Madam,” or “ Joan Madam”?

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.l: “ Madam,” and nothing else. So lords call ladies.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.l: Madam wife, they say that I have dreamed
And slept above some fifteen year or more.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me,
Being all this time abandoned from your bed.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.l: ’Tis much.— Servants, leave me and her alone.—
Madam, undress you, and come now to bed.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you
To pardon me yet for a night or two;
Or if not so, until the sun be set.
For your physicians have expressly charged,
In peril to incur your former malady,
That I should yet absent me from your bed.
I hope this reason stands for my excuse.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long; but
I would be loath to fall into my dreams again. I will
therefore tarry in despite of the flesh and the
blood.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Your Honor’s players, hearing your amendment,
Are come to play a pleasant comedy,
For so your doctors hold it very meet,
Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood,
And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.
Therefore they thought it good you hear a play
And frame your mind to mirth and merriment,
Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: Marry, I will. Let them play it.

Is not a comonty a Christmas gambold or a tumbling
trick?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.l: No, my good lord, it is more pleasing stuff.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p: What, household stuff?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: It is a kind of history.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
Well, we’ll see ’t. Come, madam wife, sit by my
side, and let the world slip. We shall ne’er be
younger.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Flourish. Enter Lucentio and his man Tranio.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Tranio, since for the great desire I had
To see fair Padua, nursery of arts,
I am arrived for fruitful Lombardy,
The pleasant garden of great Italy,
And by my father’s love and leave am armed
With his goodwill and thy good company.
My trusty servant well approved in all,
Here let us breathe and haply institute
A course of learning and ingenious studies.
Pisa, renownèd for grave citizens,
Gave me my being, and my father first,
A merchant of great traffic through the world,
Vincentio, come of the Bentivolii.
Vincentio’s son, brought up in Florence,
It shall become to serve all hopes conceived
To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds.
And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study
Virtue, and that part of philosophy
Will I apply that treats of happiness
By virtue specially to be achieved.
Tell me thy mind, for I have Pisa left
And am to Padua come, as he that leaves
A shallow plash to plunge him in the deep
And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Mi perdonato, gentle master mine.
I am in all affected as yourself,
Glad that you thus continue your resolve
To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.
Only, good master, while we do admire
This virtue and this moral discipline,
Let’s be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray,
Or so devote to Aristotle’s checks
As Ovid be an outcast quite abjured.
Balk logic with acquaintance that you have,
And practice rhetoric in your common talk;
Music and poesy use to quicken you;
The mathematics and the metaphysics—
Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you.
No profit grows where is no pleasure ta’en.
In brief, sir, study what you most affect.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.
If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore,
We could at once put us in readiness
And take a lodging fit to entertain
Such friends as time in Padua shall beget.
sp.stage: Enter Baptista with his two daughters, Katherine and Bianca; Gremio, a pantaloon, and Hortensio, suitors to Bianca.
sp.l: But stay awhile! What company is this?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Master, some show to welcome us to town.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
For how I firmly am resolved you know:
That is, not to bestow my youngest daughter
Before I have a husband for the elder.
If either of you both love Katherine,
Because I know you well and love you well,
Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: To cart her, rather. She’s too rough for me.—
There, there, Hortensio, will you any wife?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: I pray you, sir, is it your will
To make a stale of me amongst these mates?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: “ Mates,” maid? How mean you that? No mates for you,
Unless you were of gentler, milder mold.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: I’ faith, sir, you shall never need to fear.
Iwis it is not halfway to her heart.
But if it were, doubt not her care should be
To comb your noddle with a three-legged stool
And paint your face and use you like a fool.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: From all such devils, good Lord, deliver us!

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p: And me too, good Lord.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Husht, master, here’s some good pastime toward;
That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: But in the other’s silence do I see
Maid’s mild behavior and sobriety.
Peace, Tranio.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Well said, master. Mum, and gaze your fill.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Gentlemen, that I may soon make good
What I have said— Bianca, get you in,
And let it not displease thee, good Bianca,
For I will love thee ne’er the less, my girl.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: A pretty peat! It is best
Put finger in the eye, an she knew why.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: Sister, content you in my discontent.—
Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe.
My books and instruments shall be my company,
On them to look and practice by myself.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Hark, Tranio, thou mayst hear Minerva speak!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?
Sorry am I that our goodwill effects
Bianca’s grief.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Why will you mew her up,
Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell,
And make her bear the penance of her tongue?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Gentlemen, content you. I am resolved.—
Go in, Bianca.
And for I know she taketh most delight
In music, instruments, and poetry,
Schoolmasters will I keep within my house
Fit to instruct her youth. If you, Hortensio,
Or, Signior Gremio, you know any such,
Prefer them hither. For to cunning men
I will be very kind, and liberal
To mine own children in good bringing up.
And so, farewell.— Katherine, you may stay,
For I have more to commune with Bianca.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?
What, shall I be appointed hours as though, belike,
I knew not what to take and what to leave? Ha!

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p:
You may go to the Devil’s dam! Your gifts are
so good here’s none will hold you.— Their love is
not so great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nails
together and fast it fairly out. Our cake’s dough on
both sides. Farewell. Yet for the love I bear my
sweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit
man to teach her that wherein she delights, I will
wish him to her father.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p:
So will I, Signior Gremio. But a word, I
pray. Though the nature of our quarrel yet never
brooked parle, know now upon advice, it toucheth
us both ( that we may yet again have access to our
fair mistress and be happy rivals in Bianca’s love) to
labor and effect one thing specially.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p: What’s that, I pray?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p: A husband? A devil!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p: I say “ a husband.”

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p:
I say “ a devil.” Think’st thou, Hortensio,
though her father be very rich, any man is so very a
fool to be married to hell?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p:
Tush, Gremio. Though it pass your patience
and mine to endure her loud alarums, why,
man, there be good fellows in the world, an a man
could light on them, would take her with all faults,
and money enough.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p:
I cannot tell. But I had as lief take her dowry
with this condition: to be whipped at the high cross
every morning.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p:
Faith, as you say, there’s small choice in
rotten apples. But come, since this bar in law
makes us friends, it shall be so far forth friendly
maintained till by helping Baptista’s eldest daughter
to a husband we set his youngest free for a
husband, and then have to ’t afresh. Sweet Bianca!
Happy man be his dole! He that runs fastest gets the
ring. How say you, Signior Gremio?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p:
I am agreed, and would I had given him the
best horse in Padua to begin his wooing that would
thoroughly woo her, wed her, and bed her, and rid
the house of her. Come on.

div.stage: Gremio and Hortensio exit. Tranio and Lucentio remain onstage.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible
That love should of a sudden take such hold?

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: O Tranio, till I found it to be true,
I never thought it possible or likely.
But see, while idly I stood looking on,
I found the effect of love-in-idleness,
And now in plainness do confess to thee
That art to me as secret and as dear
As Anna to the Queen of Carthage was:
Tranio, I burn, I pine! I perish, Tranio,
If I achieve not this young modest girl.
Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst.
Assist me, Tranio, for I know thou wilt.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Master, it is no time to chide you now.
Affection is not rated from the heart.
If love have touched you, naught remains but so:
Redime te captum quam queas minimo.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Gramercies, lad. Go forward. This contents;
The rest will comfort, for thy counsel’s sound.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Master, you looked so longly on the maid,
Perhaps you marked not what’s the pith of all.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: O yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face,
Such as the daughter of Agenor had,
That made great Jove to humble him to her hand
When with his knees he kissed the Cretan strand.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Saw you no more? Marked you not how her sister
Began to scold and raise up such a storm
That mortal ears might hardly endure the din?

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move,
And with her breath she did perfume the air.
Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Nay, then ’tis time to stir him from his trance.—
I pray, awake, sir! If you love the maid,
Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her. Thus it stands:
Her elder sister is so curst and shrewd
That till the father rid his hands of her,
Master, your love must live a maid at home,
And therefore has he closely mewed her up,
Because she will not be annoyed with suitors.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father’s he!
But art thou not advised he took some care
To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Ay, marry, am I, sir— and now ’tis plotted!

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: I have it, Tranio!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Master, for my hand,
Both our inventions meet and jump in one.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Tell me thine first.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: You will be schoolmaster
And undertake the teaching of the maid:
That’s your device.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: It is. May it be done?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Not possible. For who shall bear your part
And be in Padua here Vincentio’s son,
Keep house, and ply his book, welcome his friends,
Visit his countrymen and banquet them?

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Basta, content thee, for I have it full.
We have not yet been seen in any house,
Nor can we be distinguished by our faces
For man or master. Then it follows thus:
Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead,
Keep house, and port, and servants, as I should.
I will some other be, some Florentine,
Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa.
’Tis hatched, and shall be so. Tranio, at once
Uncase thee. Take my colored hat and cloak.
When Biondello comes, he waits on thee,
But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: So had you need.
In brief, sir, sith it your pleasure is,
And I am tied to be obedient
( For so your father charged me at our parting:
“ Be serviceable to my son,” quoth he,
Although I think ’twas in another sense),
I am content to be Lucentio,
Because so well I love Lucentio.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves,
And let me be a slave, t’ achieve that maid
Whose sudden sight hath thralled my wounded eye.
Here comes the rogue.— Sirrah, where have you been?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.l: Where have I been? Nay, how now, where are you?
Master, has my fellow Tranio stolen your clothes?
Or you stolen his? Or both? Pray, what’s the news?

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Sirrah, come hither. ’Tis no time to jest,
And therefore frame your manners to the time.
Your fellow, Tranio here, to save my life,
Puts my apparel and my count’nance on,
And I for my escape have put on his;
For in a quarrel since I came ashore
I killed a man and fear I was descried.
Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes,
While I make way from hence to save my life.
You understand me?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.l: Ay, sir. Aside. Ne’er a whit.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: And not a jot of “ Tranio” in your mouth.
Tranio is changed into Lucentio.

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.l: The better for him. Would I were so too.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after,
That Lucentio indeed had Baptista’s youngest daughter.
But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master’s, I advise
You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies.
When I am alone, why then I am Tranio;
But in all places else, your master Lucentio.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.p:
Tranio, let’s go. One thing more rests, that
thyself execute, to make one among these wooers. If
thou ask me why, sufficeth my reasons are both
good and weighty.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: My lord, you nod. You do not mind the play.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
Yes, by Saint Anne, do I. A good matter, surely.
Comes there any more of it?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: My lord, ’tis but begun.

sp.speaker: SLY
sp.p:
’Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady.
Would ’twere done.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Petruchio and his man Grumio.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Verona, for a while I take my leave
To see my friends in Padua, but of all
My best belovèd and approvèd friend,
Hortensio. And I trow this is his house.
Here, sirrah Grumio, knock, I say.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
Knock, sir? Whom should I knock? Is there
any man has rebused your Worship?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
Knock you here, sir? Why, sir, what am I, sir,
that I should knock you here, sir?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Villain, I say, knock me at this gate
And rap me well, or I’ll knock your knave’s pate.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.l: My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knock you first,
And then I know after who comes by the worst.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Will it not be?
Faith, sirrah, an you’ll not knock, I’ll ring it.
I’ll try how you can sol, fa, and sing it.

div.stage: He wrings him by the ears. Grumio falls.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: Help, mistress, help! My master is mad.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p:
Now knock when I bid you, sirrah
villain.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p:
How now, what’s the matter? My old
friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio? How
do you all at Verona?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?
Con tutto il cuore ben trovato, may I say.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p:
Alia nostra casa ben venuto, molto
honorato signor mio Petruchio.— Rise, Grumio,
rise. We will compound this quarrel.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
Nay, ’tis no matter, sir, what he ’leges in
Latin. If this be not a lawful cause for me to leave
his service— look you, sir: he bid me knock him
and rap him soundly, sir. Well, was it fit for a
servant to use his master so, being perhaps, for
aught I see, two-and-thirty, a pip out?
sp.l: Whom, would to God, I had well knocked at first,
Then had not Grumio come by the worst.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: A senseless villain, good Hortensio.
I bade the rascal knock upon your gate
And could not get him for my heart to do it.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
Knock at the gate? O, heavens, spake you not
these words plain: “ Sirrah, knock me here, rap me
here, knock me well, and knock me soundly”? And
come you now with “ knocking at the gate”?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Sirrah, begone, or talk not, I advise you.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Petruchio, patience. I am Grumio’s pledge.
Why, this’ a heavy chance ’twixt him and you,
Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.
And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale
Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Such wind as scatters young men through the world
To seek their fortunes farther than at home,
Where small experience grows. But in a few,
Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me:
Antonio, my father, is deceased,
And I have thrust myself into this maze,
Happily to wive and thrive, as best I may.
Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home,
And so am come abroad to see the world.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee
And wish thee to a shrewd ill-favored wife?
Thou ’dst thank me but a little for my counsel—
And yet I’ll promise thee she shall be rich,
And very rich. But thou ’rt too much my friend,
And I’ll not wish thee to her.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Signior Hortensio, ’twixt such friends as we
Few words suffice. And therefore, if thou know
One rich enough to be Petruchio’s wife
( As wealth is burden of my wooing dance),
Be she as foul as was Florentius’ love,
As old as Sibyl, and as curst and shrewd
As Socrates’ Xanthippe, or a worse,
She moves me not, or not removes at least
Affection’s edge in me, were she as rough
As are the swelling Adriatic seas.
I come to wive it wealthily in Padua;
If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
Nay, look you, sir, he tells you
flatly what his mind is. Why, give him gold enough
and marry him to a puppet or an aglet-baby, or an
old trot with ne’er a tooth in her head, though she
have as many diseases as two-and-fifty horses. Why,
nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Petruchio, since we are stepped thus far in,
I will continue that I broached in jest.
I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife
With wealth enough, and young and beauteous,
Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.
Her only fault, and that is faults enough,
Is that she is intolerable curst,
And shrewd, and froward, so beyond all measure
That, were my state far worser than it is,
I would not wed her for a mine of gold.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Hortensio, peace. Thou know’st not gold’s effect.
Tell me her father’s name, and ’tis enough;
For I will board her, though she chide as loud
As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Her father is Baptista Minola,
An affable and courteous gentleman.
Her name is Katherina Minola,
Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I know her father, though I know not her,
And he knew my deceasèd father well.
I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her,
And therefore let me be thus bold with you
To give you over at this first encounter—
Unless you will accompany me thither.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
I pray you, sir, let him go while
the humor lasts. O’ my word, an she knew him as
well as I do, she would think scolding would do little
good upon him. She may perhaps call him half a
score knaves or so. Why, that’s nothing; an he begin
once, he’ll rail in his rope tricks. I’ll tell you what,
sir, an she stand him but a little, he will throw a
figure in her face and so disfigure her with it that
she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat.
You know him not, sir.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Tarry, Petruchio. I must go with thee,
For in Baptista’s keep my treasure is.
He hath the jewel of my life in hold,
His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca,
And her withholds from me and other more,
Suitors to her and rivals in my love,
Supposing it a thing impossible,
For those defects I have before rehearsed,
That ever Katherina will be wooed.
Therefore this order hath Baptista ta’en,
That none shall have access unto Bianca
Till Katherine the curst have got a husband.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.l: “ Katherine the curst,”
A title for a maid, of all titles the worst.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace
And offer me disguised in sober robes
To old Baptista as a schoolmaster
Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca,
That so I may, by this device at least,
Have leave and leisure to make love to her
And unsuspected court her by herself.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
Here’s no knavery! See, to beguile the old
folks, how the young folks lay their heads together!
sp.stage: Enter Gremio and Lucentio, disguised as Cambio, a schoolmaster.
sp.p: Master, master, look about you. Who goes there, ha?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Peace, Grumio, it is the rival of my love.
Petruchio, stand by awhile.

div.stage: Petruchio, Hortensio, and Grumio stand aside.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.l: A proper stripling, and an amorous.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: O, very well, I have perused the note.
Hark you, sir, I’ll have them very fairly bound,
All books of love. See that at any hand,
And see you read no other lectures to her.
You understand me. Over and beside
Signior Baptista’s liberality,
I’ll mend it with a largess. Take your paper too.
And let me have them very well perfumed,
For she is sweeter than perfume itself
To whom they go to. What will you read to her?

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Whate’er I read to her, I’ll plead for you
As for my patron, stand you so assured,
As firmly as yourself were still in place,
Yea, and perhaps with more successful words
Than you— unless you were a scholar, sir.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: O this learning, what a thing it is!

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.l: O this woodcock, what an ass it is!

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: Peace, sirrah.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Grumio, mum.
God save you, Signior Gremio.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.
Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola.
I promised to enquire carefully
About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca,
And by good fortune I have lighted well
On this young man, for learning and behavior
Fit for her turn, well read in poetry
And other books— good ones, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: ’Tis well. And I have met a gentleman
Hath promised me to help me to another,
A fine musician to instruct our mistress.
So shall I no whit be behind in duty
To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Beloved of me, and that my deeds shall prove.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p: And that his bags shall prove.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Gremio, ’tis now no time to vent our love.
Listen to me, and if you speak me fair
I’ll tell you news indifferent good for either.
Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met,
Upon agreement from us to his liking,
Will undertake to woo curst Katherine,
Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: So said, so done, is well.
Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I know she is an irksome, brawling scold.
If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: No? Sayst me so, friend? What countryman?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Born in Verona, old Antonio’s son.
My father dead, my fortune lives for me,
And I do hope good days and long to see.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Oh, sir, such a life with such a wife were strange.
But if you have a stomach, to ’t, i’ God’s name!
You shall have me assisting you in all.
But will you woo this wildcat?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Will I live?

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.l: Will he woo her? Ay, or I’ll hang her.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Why came I hither but to that intent?
Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?
Have I not in my time heard lions roar?
Have I not heard the sea, puffed up with winds,
Rage like an angry boar chafèd with sweat?
Have I not heard great ordnance in the field
And heaven’s artillery thunder in the skies?
Have I not in a pitchèd battle heard
Loud ’larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets clang?
And do you tell me of a woman’s tongue,
That gives not half so great a blow to hear
As will a chestnut in a farmer’s fire?
Tush, tush, fear boys with bugs!

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.l: For he fears none.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Hortensio, hark.
This gentleman is happily arrived,
My mind presumes, for his own good and yours.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: I promised we would be contributors
And bear his charge of wooing whatsoe’er.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: And so we will, provided that he win her.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.l: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.

div.stage: Enter Tranio, disguised as Lucentio, and Biondello.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold,
Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest way
To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p:
He that has the two fair daughters— is ’t
he you mean?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: Even he, Biondello.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Hark you, sir, you mean not her to—

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Perhaps him and her, sir. What have you to do?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: I love no chiders, sir. Biondello, let’s away.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Well begun, Tranio.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Sir, a word ere you go.
Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: An if I be, sir, is it any offense?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: No, if without more words you will get you hence.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Why sir, I pray, are not the streets as free
For me, as for you?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: But so is not she.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: For what reason, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: For this reason, if you’ll know:
That she’s the choice love of Signior Gremio.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: That she’s the chosen of Signior Hortensio.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Softly, my masters. If you be gentlemen,
Do me this right: hear me with patience.
Baptista is a noble gentleman
To whom my father is not all unknown,
And were his daughter fairer than she is,
She may more suitors have, and me for one.
Fair Leda’s daughter had a thousand wooers.
Then well one more may fair Bianca have.
And so she shall. Lucentio shall make one,
Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: What, this gentleman will out-talk us all!

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Sir, give him head; I know he’ll prove a jade.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,
Did you yet ever see Baptista’s daughter?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: No, sir, but hear I do that he hath two,
The one as famous for a scolding tongue
As is the other for beauteous modesty.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Sir, sir, the first’s for me; let her go by.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules,
And let it be more than Alcides’ twelve.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Sir, understand you this of me, in sooth:
The youngest daughter, whom you hearken for,
Her father keeps from all access of suitors
And will not promise her to any man
Until the elder sister first be wed.
The younger then is free, and not before.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: If it be so, sir, that you are the man
Must stead us all, and me amongst the rest,
And if you break the ice and do this feat,
Achieve the elder, set the younger free
For our access, whose hap shall be to have her
Will not so graceless be to be ingrate.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive.
And since you do profess to be a suitor,
You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman,
To whom we all rest generally beholding.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Sir, I shall not be slack; in sign whereof,
Please you we may contrive this afternoon
And quaff carouses to our mistress’ health,
And do as adversaries do in law,
Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO and BIONDELLO
sp.l: O excellent motion! Fellows, let’s be gone.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: The motion’s good indeed, and be it so.—
Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Katherine and Bianca with her hands tied.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself,
To make a bondmaid and a slave of me.
That I disdain. But for these other goods—
Unbind my hands, I’ll pull them off myself,
Yea, all my raiment to my petticoat,
Or what you will command me will I do,
So well I know my duty to my elders.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Of all thy suitors here I charge thee tell
Whom thou lov’st best. See thou dissemble not.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: Believe me, sister, of all the men alive
I never yet beheld that special face
Which I could fancy more than any other.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Minion, thou liest. Is ’t not Hortensio?

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: If you affect him, sister, here I swear
I’ll plead for you myself, but you shall have him.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: O, then belike you fancy riches more.
You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: Is it for him you do envy me so?
Nay, then, you jest, and now I well perceive
You have but jested with me all this while.
I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Why, how now, dame, whence grows this insolence?—
Bianca, stand aside.— Poor girl, she weeps!
To Bianca. Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.
To Katherine. For shame, thou hilding of a devilish spirit!
Why dost thou wrong her that did ne’er wrong thee?
When did she cross thee with a bitter word?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Her silence flouts me, and I’ll be revenged!

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: What, in my sight?— Bianca, get thee in.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: What, will you not suffer me? Nay, now I see
She is your treasure, she must have a husband,
I must dance barefoot on her wedding day
And, for your love to her, lead apes in hell.
Talk not to me. I will go sit and weep
Till I can find occasion of revenge.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I?
But who comes here?

div.stage: Enter Gremio; Lucentio disguised as Cambio in the habit of a mean man; Petruchio with Hortensio disguised as Litio; and Tranio disguised as Lucentio, with his boy, Biondello bearing a lute and books.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p: Good morrow, neighbor Baptista.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p:
Good morrow, neighbor Gremio.— God
save you, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: And you, good sir. Pray, have you not a daughter
Called Katherina, fair and virtuous?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: I have a daughter, sir, called Katherina.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: You are too blunt. Go to it orderly.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: You wrong me, Signior Gremio. Give me leave.—
I am a gentleman of Verona, sir,
That hearing of her beauty and her wit,
Her affability and bashful modesty,
Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior,
Am bold to show myself a forward guest
Within your house, to make mine eye the witness
Of that report which I so oft have heard,
And, for an entrance to my entertainment,
I do present you with a man of mine,
Cunning in music and the mathematics,
To instruct her fully in those sciences,
Whereof I know she is not ignorant.
Accept of him, or else you do me wrong.
His name is Litio, born in Mantua.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: You’re welcome, sir, and he for your good sake.
But for my daughter Katherine, this I know,
She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I see you do not mean to part with her,
Or else you like not of my company.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Mistake me not. I speak but as I find.
Whence are you, sir? What may I call your name?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Petruchio is my name, Antonio’s son,
A man well known throughout all Italy.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: I know him well. You are welcome for his sake.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray
Let us that are poor petitioners speak too!
Bacare, you are marvelous forward.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I would fain be doing.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: I doubt it not, sir. But you will curse your wooing.
sp.p:
To Baptista. Neighbor, this is a gift very grateful,
I am sure of it. To express the like kindness, myself,
that have been more kindly beholding to you than
any, freely give unto you this young scholar

that hath
been long studying at Rheims, as cunning in Greek,
Latin, and other languages as the other in music and
mathematics. His name is Cambio. Pray accept his
service.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p:
A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.— Welcome,
good Cambio. To Tranio as Lucentio. But,
gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger. May I
be so bold to know the cause of your coming?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own,
That being a stranger in this city here
Do make myself a suitor to your daughter,
Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.
Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me,
In the preferment of the eldest sister.
This liberty is all that I request,
That, upon knowledge of my parentage,
I may have welcome ’mongst the rest that woo
And free access and favor as the rest.
And toward the education of your daughters
I here bestow a simple instrument
And this small packet of Greek and Latin books.
sp.stage: Biondello comes forward with the gifts.
sp.l: If you accept them, then their worth is great.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Lucentio is your name. Of whence, I pray?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Of Pisa, sir, son to Vincentio.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: A mighty man of Pisa. By report
I know him well. You are very welcome, sir.
To Hortensio as Litio. Take you the lute, To Lucentio as Cambio. and you the set of books.
You shall go see your pupils presently.
Holla, within!
Sirrah, lead these gentlemen
To my daughters, and tell them both
These are their tutors. Bid them use them well.
sp.stage: Servant exits with Hortensio and Lucentio.
sp.l: We will go walk a little in the orchard,
And then to dinner. You are passing welcome,
And so I pray you all to think yourselves.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste,
And every day I cannot come to woo.
You knew my father well, and in him me,
Left solely heir to all his lands and goods,
Which I have bettered rather than decreased.
Then tell me, if I get your daughter’s love,
What dowry shall I have with her to wife?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: After my death, the one half of my lands,
And, in possession, twenty thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: And, for that dowry, I’ll assure her of
Her widowhood, be it that she survive me,
In all my lands and leases whatsoever.
Let specialties be therefore drawn between us,
That covenants may be kept on either hand.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Ay, when the special thing is well obtained,
That is, her love, for that is all in all.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Why, that is nothing. For I tell you, father,
I am as peremptory as she proud-minded;
And where two raging fires meet together,
They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.
Though little fire grows great with little wind,
Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all.
So I to her and so she yields to me,
For I am rough and woo not like a babe.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed.
But be thou armed for some unhappy words.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Ay, to the proof, as mountains are for winds,
That shakes not, though they blow perpetually.

div.stage: Enter Hortensio as Litio with his head broke.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: How now, my friend, why dost thou look so pale?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: I think she’ll sooner prove a soldier!
Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Why, no, for she hath broke the lute to me.
I did but tell her she mistook her frets,
And bowed her hand to teach her fingering,
When, with a most impatient devilish spirit,
“‘ Frets’ call you these?” quoth she. “ I’ll fume with them!”
And with that word she struck me on the head,
And through the instrument my pate made way,
And there I stood amazèd for a while,
As on a pillory, looking through the lute,
While she did call me “ rascal fiddler,”
And “ twangling Jack,” with twenty such vile terms,
As had she studied to misuse me so.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench.
I love her ten times more than ere I did.
O, how I long to have some chat with her!

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Well, go with me, and be not so discomfited.
Proceed in practice with my younger daughter.
She’s apt to learn, and thankful for good turns.—
Signior Petruchio, will you go with us,
Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I pray you do. I’ll attend her here—
And woo her with some spirit when she comes!
Say that she rail, why then I’ll tell her plain
She sings as sweetly as a nightingale.
Say that she frown, I’ll say she looks as clear
As morning roses newly washed with dew.
Say she be mute and will not speak a word,
Then I’ll commend her volubility
And say she uttereth piercing eloquence.
If she do bid me pack, I’ll give her thanks
As though she bid me stay by her a week.
If she deny to wed, I’ll crave the day
When I shall ask the banns, and when be marrièd.
But here she comes— and now, Petruchio, speak.
Good morrow, Kate, for that’s your name, I hear.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing.
They call me Katherine that do talk of me.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: You lie, in faith, for you are called plain Kate,
And bonny Kate, and sometimes Kate the curst.
But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom,
Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate
( For dainties are all Kates)— and therefore, Kate,
Take this of me, Kate of my consolation:
Hearing thy mildness praised in every town,
Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded
( Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs),
Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: “ Moved,” in good time! Let him that moved you hither
Remove you hence. I knew you at the first
You were a movable.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Why, what’s a movable?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: A joint stool.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Thou hast hit it. Come, sit on me.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: No such jade as you, if me you mean.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Alas, good Kate, I will not burden thee,
For knowing thee to be but young and light—

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Too light for such a swain as you to catch,
And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: “ Should be”— should buzz!

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Well ta’en, and like a buzzard.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: O slow-winged turtle, shall a buzzard take thee?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Come, come, you wasp! I’ faith, you are too angry.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: My remedy is then to pluck it out.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting?
In his tail.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: In his tongue.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: Whose tongue?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Yours, if you talk of tales, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: What, with my tongue in your tail?
Nay, come again, good Kate. I am a gentleman—

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: That I’ll try.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I swear I’ll cuff you if you strike again.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: So may you lose your arms.
If you strike me, you are no gentleman,
And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: A herald, Kate? O, put me in thy books.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: What is your crest? A coxcomb?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: No cock of mine. You crow too like a craven.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Nay, come, Kate, come. You must not look so sour.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: It is my fashion when I see a crab.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Why, here’s no crab, and therefore look not sour.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: There is, there is.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Then show it me.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Had I a glass, I would.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: What, you mean my face?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Well aimed of such a young one.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Yet you are withered.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: ’Tis with cares.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: I care not.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Nay, hear you, Kate— in sooth, you ’scape not so.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: I chafe you if I tarry. Let me go.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: No, not a whit. I find you passing gentle.
’Twas told me you were rough, and coy, and sullen,
And now I find report a very liar.
For thou art pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous,
But slow in speech, yet sweet as springtime flowers.
Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance,
Nor bite the lip as angry wenches will,
Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk.
But thou with mildness entertain’st thy wooers,
With gentle conference, soft, and affable.
Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?
O sland’rous world! Kate like the hazel twig
Is straight, and slender, and as brown in hue
As hazelnuts, and sweeter than the kernels.
O, let me see thee walk! Thou dost not halt.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Go, fool, and whom thou keep’st command.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Did ever Dian so become a grove
As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?
O, be thou Dian and let her be Kate,
And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Where did you study all this goodly speech?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: It is extempore, from my mother wit.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: A witty mother, witless else her son.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: Am I not wise?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: Yes, keep you warm.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katherine, in thy bed.
And therefore, setting all this chat aside,
Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented
That you shall be my wife, your dowry ’greed on,
And, will you, nill you, I will marry you.
Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn,
For by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,
Thy beauty that doth make me like thee well,
Thou must be married to no man but me.
For I am he am born to tame you, Kate,
And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate
Conformable as other household Kates.
sp.stage: Enter Baptista, Gremio, and Tranio as Lucentio.
sp.l: Here comes your father. Never make denial.
I must and will have Katherine to my wife.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: How but well, sir? How but well?
It were impossible I should speed amiss.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Why, how now, daughter Katherine? In your dumps?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Call you me daughter? Now I promise you
You have showed a tender fatherly regard,
To wish me wed to one half lunatic,
A madcap ruffian and a swearing Jack,
That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Father, ’tis thus: yourself and all the world
That talked of her have talked amiss of her.
If she be curst, it is for policy,
For she’s not froward, but modest as the dove;
She is not hot, but temperate as the morn.
For patience she will prove a second Grissel,
And Roman Lucrece for her chastity.
And to conclude, we have ’greed so well together
That upon Sunday is the wedding day.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: I’ll see thee hanged on Sunday first.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p:
Hark, Petruchio, she says she’ll see thee
hanged first.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p:
Is this your speeding? Nay,
then, goodnight our part.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Be patient, gentlemen. I choose her for myself.
If she and I be pleased, what’s that to you?
’Tis bargained ’twixt us twain, being alone,
That she shall still be curst in company.
I tell you, ’tis incredible to believe
How much she loves me. O, the kindest Kate!
She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss
She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath,
That in a twink she won me to her love.
O, you are novices! ’Tis a world to see
How tame, when men and women are alone,
A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.—
Give me thy hand, Kate. I will unto Venice
To buy apparel ’gainst the wedding day.—
Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests.
I will be sure my Katherine shall be fine.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: I know not what to say, but give me your hands.
God send you joy, Petruchio. ’Tis a match.

sp.speaker: GREMIO and TRANIO
sp.l: Amen, say we. We will be witnesses.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.
I will to Venice. Sunday comes apace.
We will have rings, and things, and fine array,
And kiss me, Kate. We will be married o’ Sunday.

div.stage: Petruchio and Katherine exit through different doors.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Was ever match clapped up so suddenly?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant’s part
And venture madly on a desperate mart.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: ’Twas a commodity lay fretting by you.
’Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: The gain I seek, is quiet in the match.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.
But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter.
Now is the day we long have lookèd for.
I am your neighbor and was suitor first.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: And I am one that love Bianca more
Than words can witness or your thoughts can guess.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: But thine doth fry!
Skipper, stand back. ’Tis age that nourisheth.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: But youth in ladies’ eyes that flourisheth.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Content you, gentlemen. I will compound this strife.
’Tis deeds must win the prize, and he of both
That can assure my daughter greatest dower
Shall have my Bianca’s love.
Say, Signior Gremio, what can you assure her?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: First, as you know, my house within the city
Is richly furnishèd with plate and gold,
Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands;
My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry;
In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns,
In cypress chests my arras counterpoints,
Costly apparel, tents, and canopies,
Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl,
Valance of Venice gold in needlework,
Pewter and brass, and all things that belongs
To house or housekeeping. Then, at my farm
I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail,
Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls,
And all things answerable to this portion.
Myself am struck in years, I must confess,
And if I die tomorrow this is hers,
If whilst I live she will be only mine.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: That “ only” came well in. To Baptista. Sir, list to me:
I am my father’s heir and only son.
If I may have your daughter to my wife,
I’ll leave her houses three or four as good,
Within rich Pisa walls, as any one
Old Signior Gremio has in Padua,
Besides two thousand ducats by the year
Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.—
What, have I pinched you, Signior Gremio?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Two thousand ducats by the year of land?
Aside. My land amounts not to so much in all.—
That she shall have, besides an argosy
That now is lying in Marcellus’ road.
To Tranio. What, have I choked you with an argosy?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Gremio, ’tis known my father hath no less
Than three great argosies, besides two galliasses
And twelve tight galleys. These I will assure her,
And twice as much whate’er thou off’rest next.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Nay, I have offered all. I have no more,
And she can have no more than all I have.
To Baptista. If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Why, then, the maid is mine from all the world,
By your firm promise. Gremio is outvied.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: I must confess your offer is the best,
And, let your father make her the assurance,
She is your own; else, you must pardon me.
If you should die before him, where’s her dower?

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: That’s but a cavil. He is old, I young.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: And may not young men die as well as old?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolved:
On Sunday next, you know
My daughter Katherine is to be married.
To Tranio as Lucentio. Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca
Be bride to you, if you make this assurance.
If not, to Signior Gremio.
And so I take my leave, and thank you both.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Adieu, good neighbor.
Now I fear thee not.
Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool
To give thee all and in his waning age
Set foot under thy table. Tut, a toy!
An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide!—
Yet I have faced it with a card of ten.
’Tis in my head to do my master good.
I see no reason but supposed Lucentio
Must get a father, called “ supposed Vincentio”—
And that’s a wonder. Fathers commonly
Do get their children. But in this case of wooing,
A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Lucentio as Cambio, Hortensio as Litio, and Bianca.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Fiddler, forbear. You grow too forward, sir.
Have you so soon forgot the entertainment
Her sister Katherine welcomed you withal?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: But, wrangling pedant, this is
The patroness of heavenly harmony.
Then give me leave to have prerogative,
And when in music we have spent an hour,
Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Preposterous ass, that never read so far
To know the cause why music was ordained.
Was it not to refresh the mind of man
After his studies or his usual pain?
Then give me leave to read philosophy,
And, while I pause, serve in your harmony.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong
To strive for that which resteth in my choice.
I am no breeching scholar in the schools.
I’ll not be tied to hours, nor ’pointed times,
But learn my lessons as I please myself.
And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down.
To Hortensio. Take you your instrument, play you the whiles;
His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: You’ll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: That will be never. To Hortensio. Tune your instrument.

div.stage: Hortensio steps aside to tune his lute.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.p: Where left we last?

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.p: Here, madam:
sp.l: Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus,
Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.p: Conster them.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.p:
Hic ibat, as I told you before, Simois, I am
Lucentio, hic est, son unto Vincentio of Pisa,
Sigeia tellus, disguised thus to get your love, Hic
steterat, and that “ Lucentio” that comes a-wooing,
Priami, is my man Tranio, regia, bearing my port,
celsa senis, that we might beguile the old pantaloon.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.p:
Madam, my instrument’s in
tune.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.p: Let’s hear. He plays. Oh fie, the treble jars!

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.p:
Spit in the hole, man, and tune
again.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.p:
Now let me see if I can conster it. Hic ibat
Simois, I know you not; hic est Sigeia tellus, I trust
you not; Hic steterat Priami, take heed he hear us
not; regia, presume not; celsa senis, despair not.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Madam, ’tis now in tune.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: All but the bass.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: The bass is right. ’Tis the base knave that jars.
Aside. How fiery and forward our pedant is.
Now for my life the knave doth court my love!
Pedascule, I’ll watch you better yet.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Mistrust it not, for sure Aeacides
Was Ajax, called so from his grandfather.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: I must believe my master; else, I promise you,
I should be arguing still upon that doubt.
But let it rest.— Now, Litio, to you.
Good master, take it not unkindly, pray,
That I have been thus pleasant with you both.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: You may go walk, and give me leave awhile.
My lessons make no music in three parts.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Are you so formal, sir? Well, I must wait
Aside. And watch withal, for, but I be deceived,
Our fine musician groweth amorous.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Madam, before you touch the instrument,
To learn the order of my fingering
I must begin with rudiments of art,
To teach you gamut in a briefer sort,
More pleasant, pithy, and effectual
Than hath been taught by any of my trade.
And there it is in writing fairly drawn.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: “ Gamut I am, the ground of all accord:
A re, to plead Hortensio’s passion;
B mi, Bianca, take him for thy lord,
C fa ut, that loves with all affection;
D sol re, one clef, two notes have I;
E la mi, show pity or I die.”
Call you this “ gamut”? Tut, I like it not.
Old fashions please me best. I am not so nice
To change true rules for odd inventions.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books
And help to dress your sister’s chamber up.
You know tomorrow is the wedding day.

sp.speaker: BIANCA
sp.l: Farewell, sweet masters both. I must be gone.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.

div.stage: Bianca, the Servant, and Lucentio exit.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIO
sp.l: But I have cause to pry into this pedant.
Methinks he looks as though he were in love.
Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble
To cast thy wand’ring eyes on every stale,
Seize thee that list! If once I find thee ranging,
Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Baptista, Gremio, Tranio as Lucentio, Katherine, Bianca, Lucentio as Cambio, and others, Attendants.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Signior Lucentio, this is the ’pointed day
That Katherine and Petruchio should be married,
And yet we hear not of our son-in-law.
What will be said? What mockery will it be,
To want the bridegroom when the priest attends
To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage?
What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: No shame but mine. I must, forsooth, be forced
To give my hand, opposed against my heart,
Unto a mad-brain rudesby, full of spleen,
Who wooed in haste and means to wed at leisure.
I told you, I, he was a frantic fool,
Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior,
And, to be noted for a merry man,
He’ll woo a thousand, ’point the day of marriage,
Make friends, invite, and proclaim the banns,
Yet never means to wed where he hath wooed.
Now must the world point at poor Katherine
And say “ Lo, there is mad Petruchio’s wife,
If it would please him come and marry her.”

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Patience, good Katherine, and Baptista too.
Upon my life, Petruchio means but well,
Whatever fortune stays him from his word.
Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;
Though he be merry, yet withal he’s honest.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Would Katherine had never seen him, though!

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Go, girl. I cannot blame thee now to weep,
For such an injury would vex a very saint,
Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor.

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p:
Master, master, news! And such old
news as you never heard of!

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Is it new and old too? How may that be?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p:
Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio’s
coming?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p: Is he come?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p: Why, no, sir.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.l: He is coming.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: When will he be here?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.l: When he stands where I am, and sees you there.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p: But say, what to thine old news?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p:
Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and
an old jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned,
a pair of boots that have been candle-cases, one
buckled, another laced; an old rusty sword ta’en
out of the town armory, with a broken hilt, and
chapeless; with two broken points; his horse
hipped, with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no
kindred, besides possessed with the glanders and
like to mose in the chine, troubled with the lampass,
infected with the fashions, full of windgalls,
sped with spavins, rayed with the yellows, past cure
of the fives, stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn
with the bots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten,
near-legged before, and with a half-checked
bit and a headstall of sheep’s leather,
which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling,
hath been often burst, and now repaired with
knots; one girth six times pieced, and a woman’s
crupper of velour, which hath two letters for her
name fairly set down in studs, and here and there
pieced with packthread.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p: Who comes with him?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p:
Oh, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisoned
like the horse: with a linen stock on one leg
and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with
a red and blue list; an old hat, and the humor of
forty fancies pricked in ’t for a feather. A monster,
a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian
footboy or a gentleman’s lackey.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: ’Tis some odd humor pricks him to this fashion,
Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-appareled.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: I am glad he’s come, howsoe’er he comes.

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p: Why, sir, he comes not.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p: Didst thou not say he comes?

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p: Who? That Petruchio came?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p: Ay, that Petruchio came!

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.p:
No, sir, I say his horse comes with him on
his back.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p: Why, that’s all one.

sp.speaker: BIONDELLO
sp.l: Nay, by Saint Jamy.
I hold you a penny,
A horse and a man
Is more than one,
And yet not many.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Come, where be these gallants? Who’s at home?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p: You are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: And yet I come not well.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.p: And yet you halt not.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.p:
Not so well appareled as I wish
you were.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Were it better I should rush in thus—
But where is Kate? Where is my lovely bride?
How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown.
And wherefore gaze this goodly company
As if they saw some wondrous monument,
Some comet or unusual prodigy?

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day.
First were we sad, fearing you would not come,
Now sadder that you come so unprovided.
Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate,
An eyesore to our solemn festival.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: And tell us what occasion of import
Hath all so long detained you from your wife
And sent you hither so unlike yourself.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear.
Sufficeth I am come to keep my word,
Though in some part enforcèd to digress,
Which at more leisure I will so excuse
As you shall well be satisfied with all.
But where is Kate? I stay too long from her.
The morning wears. ’Tis time we were at church.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: See not your bride in these unreverent robes.
Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Not I, believe me. Thus I’ll visit her.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Good sooth, even thus. Therefore, ha’ done with words.
To me she’s married, not unto my clothes.
Could I repair what she will wear in me,
As I can change these poor accoutrements,
’Twere well for Kate and better for myself.
But what a fool am I to chat with you
When I should bid good morrow to my bride
And seal the title with a lovely kiss!

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: He hath some meaning in his mad attire.
We will persuade him, be it possible,
To put on better ere he go to church.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: I’ll after him, and see the event of this.

div.stage: All except Tranio and Lucentio exit.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: But, sir, to love concerneth us to add
Her father’s liking, which to bring to pass,
As I before imparted to your Worship,
I am to get a man ( whate’er he be
It skills not much, we’ll fit him to our turn),
And he shall be “ Vincentio of Pisa,”
And make assurance here in Padua
Of greater sums than I have promisèd.
So shall you quietly enjoy your hope
And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

sp.speaker: LUCENTIO
sp.l: Were it not that my fellow schoolmaster
Doth watch Bianca’s steps so narrowly,
’Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage,
Which, once performed, let all the world say no,
I’ll keep mine own despite of all the world.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: That by degrees we mean to look into,
And watch our vantage in this business.
We’ll overreach the graybeard, Gremio,
The narrow prying father, Minola,
The quaint musician, amorous Litio,
All for my master’s sake, Lucentio.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Signior Gremio, came you from the church?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: As willingly as e’er I came from school.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: A bridegroom, say you? ’Tis a groom indeed,
A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Curster than she? Why, ’tis impossible.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Why, he’s a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Why, she’s a devil, a devil, the devil’s dam.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Tut, she’s a lamb, a dove, a fool to him.
I’ll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest
Should ask if Katherine should be his wife,
“ Ay, by gog’s wouns!” quoth he, and swore so loud
That, all amazed, the priest let fall the book,
And as he stooped again to take it up,
This mad-brained bridegroom took him such a cuff
That down fell priest and book, and book and priest.
“ Now, take them up,” quoth he, “ if any list.”

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: What said the wench when he rose again?

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.l: Trembled and shook, for why he stamped and swore
As if the vicar meant to cozen him.
But after many ceremonies done,
He calls for wine. “ A health!” quoth he, as if
He had been aboard, carousing to his mates
After a storm; quaffed off the muscatel
And threw the sops all in the sexton’s face,
Having no other reason
But that his beard grew thin and hungerly,
And seemed to ask him sops as he was drinking.
This done, he took the bride about the neck
And kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack
That at the parting all the church did echo.
And I, seeing this, came thence for very shame,
And after me I know the rout is coming.
Such a mad marriage never was before!
Hark, hark, I hear the minstrels play.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Katherine, Bianca, Hortensio, Baptista, Grumio, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains.
I know you think to dine with me today
And have prepared great store of wedding cheer,
But so it is, my haste doth call me hence,
And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

sp.speaker: BAPTISTA
sp.l: Is ’t possible you will away tonight?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I must away today, before night come.
Make it no wonder. If you knew my business,
You would entreat me rather go than stay.
And, honest company, I thank you all,
That have beheld me give away myself
To this most patient, sweet, and virtuous wife.
Dine with my father, drink a health to me,
For I must hence, and farewell to you all.

sp.speaker: TRANIO
sp.l: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: It may not be.

sp.speaker: GREMIO
sp.p: Let me entreat you.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.p: Let me entreat you.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Are you content to stay?

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: I am content you shall entreat me stay,
But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Now, if you love me, stay.

sp.speaker: PETRUCHIO
sp.l: Grumio, my horse.

sp.speaker: GRUMIO
sp.p:
Ay, sir, they be ready; the oats have eaten the
horses.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Nay, then,
Do what thou canst, I will not go today,
No, nor tomorrow, not till I please myself.
